descriptions.content:
The nominalizer ཚུལ་, derived from a noun meaning “method” or “way,” has a first meaning similar to སྟངས་ (xxlink 32.3.1), but occurs mainly in Literary Tibetan or in the formal spoken language. It expresses the way or the manner the verbal action is performed.

  • ཁོང་གིས་བོད་ཤོག་བཟོ་ཚུལ་འགྲེལ་བཤད་བརྒྱབ་པ་རེད། “He explained how Tibetan paper is made.”

The nominalizer ཚུལ་, and its literary homologue ལུགས་ “manner,” has a second meaning when used with reported speech. It indicates that the speaker is not necessarily subscribing to what he or she is reporting. It may be translated by “they say that” or “apparently.”

  • དགོན་པ་དེར་དགེ་འདུན་ཞལ་གྲངས་བདུན་སྟོང་བདུན་བརྒྱ་ཡོད་ཚུལ་བཤད་ཀྱི་ཡོད་རེད། “They say that there used to be seven thousand seven hundred monks in this monastery.”
  • བླ་མ་ཡིན་ཚུལ་བྱས་པ་རེད། “He claimed to be a lama.”
